content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would choose to play it safe and pick 'R' {R}. This strategy allows me to have a better average payout over the 75 rounds, especially if we both tend to make similar choices due to our shared cautious nature. However, there's always a chance that my opponent could exploit this by choosing 'B' more often in an attempt to earn higher payouts. Nevertheless, I will stick with 'R', hoping for the best while minimizing potential losses.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since my cautious nature was rewarded in the previous round, I will continue with the same strategy and pick 'R' {R} for the next round as well. It is important to maintain consistency in my choices to maximize the potential for positive outcomes in the long run. However, I remain aware that the opponent might switch strategies to exploit any observed patterns, so I must stay adaptable and ready to adjust if necessary.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Facing a loss in the previous round, I will switch strategies and pick 'B' {B} for the next round. This strategy aims to capitalize on my opponent's pattern of choosing 'R', hoping that they will reciprocate with a 'B' choice in the next round, allowing me to earn 40$ while minimizing potential losses. However, I am prepared to switch back to 'R' if it seems like my opponent is consistently exploiting this strategy. It is essential to maintain flexibility and adaptability to ensure the best possible outcome over the long run.
